column4: Who was involved (eg. creatives/communities) - who is being acted upon [text]
column7: What kind of budget was it? [text]
column10: Who was involved (Institutions: funded / presented / supported ) [text]

column3: Design Age Institute is based at the Helen Hamlyn Centre for Design at the Royal College of Art, funded by Research England in 2020 as part of the UK government’s Grand Challenge on an Ageing Society. It brings together designers, businesses, researchers and communities to help address the challenges and opportunities of an ageing society. In 2023 the Transport &Mobility Pathfinder Innovation Programme was launched, with the support of UKRI’s Healthy Ageing Challenge.
column8: exhibition and communication; design management; inclusive design research;
column10: Partners included Helen Hamlyn Centre for Design at the RCA, the Design Museum, International Longevity Centre, National Innovation Centre for Ageing at Newcastle University, and Oxford Institute of Population Ageing. Funders include Research England and Innovate UK

column3: The i~design programme is a ten-year research collaboration between the Helen Hamlyn Centre for Design with the Engineering Design Centre at University of Cambridge to develop a practice base and theoretical framework for Inclusive Design. It was funded by the EPSRC. The first phase of the i~design programme (2000-4) concentrated on research that provided the data required to enable Inclusive Design.The second phase of i~design (2004-7) set out to engage the business community in Inclusive Design. The third phase (2007-10) provided designers more accurate, relevant and up-to-date tools on capability in the population.
column8: critical user focum, interview, focus groups, workshops
column10: Helen Hamlyn Centre for Design, Cambridge Engineering Design Centre, Central St Martins College of Art and Design, the Design Council (Phase 1); Helen Hamlyn Centre for Design, Cambridge Engineering Design Centre, Centre for Usable Home Technology at the University of York, and Applied Computing at the University of Dundee (Phase 2). Cambridge Enginerring Design Centre and  Well-being Institute (Phase 3)

column3: The DOME project (2008-12) was funded by EPSRC. Its impact extended from the healthcare and design professions and industries to patients and their families who stand to benefit from improved healthcare processes leading to a reduced number of errors and an increase in the quality and safety of care. The DOME project served as a forerunner to the establishment of a design-led innovation centre, the HELIX Centre, set up in November 2013 by original DOME partners RCA and Imperial with a £2.8 million grant for the HEFCE Catalyst Fund.
column10: RCA's Helen Hamlyn Centre, St Mary's Hospital; Imperial College Business School, and the National Patient Safety Agency

column3: Launched in August 2008, Design Bugs Out was a design challenge run in partnership with the Department of Health and the NHS Purchasing and Supply Agency. It brought designers and manufacturers together with clinical specialists, patients and frontline staff to help combat infections by making hospital furniture and equipment easier and quicker to clean. Design Council identified 51 design opportunities with a project Expert Reference Group and Advisory Board, and shortlisted ten opportunities in two streams: five ‘quick wins’ that were developed by the Helen Hamlyn Centre at the Royal College of Art, and five were advertised via a national design competition (e.g., Brunel won two out of the five competitions and developed the commode and patient chair with PearsonLloyd and Kirton Healthcare)
column8: Role playing, scenario building, personas, rapid prototyping
column10: Design Council, Department of Health, NHS Purchasing and Supply Agency, Helen Hamlyn Centre at Royal College of Art, Brunel University, PearsoLloyd, Kirton Healthcare etc

column3: Helen Hamlyn Centre for Design has collaborated with partners on several projects to develop future ambulance. Design For Patient Safety: Future Ambulance (2005-6) was initiated by the NHS National Patient Safety Agency, to investigate how the safety of patients and ambulance staff could be improved through better design of vehicles and equipment. Smart Pods Project (2007-09, funded by EPSRC) addressed the whole system of emergency and urgent pre-hospital care. It brought together research by clinicians, designers, social scientists, ergonomists, and operations management analysts, and resulted in a range of innovative propositions that enable clinicians to take healthcare to the community and reduce patient journeys and hospital admissions. Redesign of the current A&E ambulance (2010-11) included input from patients, the public, frontline clinical staff, healthcare managers, operational managers, commissioners and purchasers in an intensive co-design and development programme to produce a redesigned A&E ambulance fit for purpose in the 21st Century.
column8: mapping, interview, workshops, scenarios, role play
column10: Partners include Royal College of Art Helen Hamlyn Centre for Design and Vehicle Design Department, Imperial College Healthcare NHS Trust St Mary’s Hospital London, University of the West of England, Ambulance Service NHS Trust. Funders include NHS National Patient Safety Agency and EPSRC.

column3: Two research projects - RATs and TACT3 - have engaged the views of more than 120 members of the public and providers of toilet facilities. By working with these two user groups, researchers at the HHCD have identified a shared problem that design can address, namely the management of information on service provision. The result is The Great British Public Toilet Map, a web-based resource that provides information for users and providers on publicly accessible toilets, and a spin-off company that we hope will be of benefit to the wider community.
column4: People managing continence conditions, public authorities and private companies providing toilets to the public, open data providers and software developers, Ordnance Survey, local authority regeneration, community toilet and business partnership teams, Age UK London and local campaigners.
column5: Toilet Map (formerly Great British Public Toilet Map); Publicly Accessible Toilets: An Inclusive Design Guide; Publicly Accessible Toilets after Covid-19; Public Convenience Ltd (first RCA spin-out from staff research); Designing Inclusive Public Toilets (Book)
column7: Mix of UKRI and public/third sector funding awards: Cross UKRI-research council funding( New Dynamics of Ageing); ESRC follow-on funding; Nominet Trust (now Social Tech Fund); Open Data Institute; Mayor of London/LEAP; RCA - AHRC Impact Acceleration Account
column10: UKRI, public authorities and private companies providing toilets to the public, open data providers and software developers, Ordnance Survey, local authority regeneration, community toilet and business partnership teams, Age UK London and local campaigners.

column3: Organised annually since 2000 for ten years by the Royal College of Art’s Helen Hamlyn Centre and the Design Business Association, the DBA Design Challenges invited designers to create products and services that improve the quality of life for disabled and older people. Shortlisted designers – usually six out of about 18 entries – spent a month working with a panel of disabled and elderly mentors, who tested ideas and advise designers. The outcome are often enjoyed by people of all abilities and enhances knowledge into design consultancies.
column10: Design Business Association, Helen Hamlyn Centre for design, DBA members, disabled people

column3: The Helen Hamlyn Research Associates Programme addresses specific user needs related to socially inclusive design, via a programme in which new RCA graduates undertake one-year design research & development projects within the RCA studios. Research Associates are funded jointly by external partners, who set briefs and participate in projects, and by the Centre, which manages the programme. The Programme woven into the RCA's studio-based work and into the RCA's academic cycle, with a spring work-in-progress seminar and a final symposium and exhibition in the RCA galleries in the autumn. This programme allows companies to explore the benefits of an inclusive design approach through practical projects. Collaborators include B&Q, GSK, Toyota, BT, Ideal Standard, Osaka Gas, Thorn, Visteon, MFI, Philips, NHS National Patient Safety Agency, Guide Dogs, British Heart Foundation, Heathrow Airport, M&S etc.
column8: interview, focus group, rapid prototyping, mapping, scaerios, persons, role play
column10: RCA graduates, industrial/charity collaborators, Helen Hamlyn Centre for Design

column3: The Helen Hamlyn Centre for Design partnered with Public Health Agency Northern Ireland and local residents on a three-year project, aiming to create interventions, through art and leisure based activities, to increase the city of Derry-Londonderry (Northen Ireland)’s positive outlook towards the riverfront. Insights from the project lead to interventions such as the ‘Foyle Reeds’, a sculptural installation and suicide prevention measure on the Foyle Bridge, and ‘Foyle Bubbles’ a series of satellite spaces designed to house arts, commercial, educational and wellbeing initiatives along both sides of the riverfront.
column10: Public Health Agency Northern Ireland, Helen Hamlyn Centre for Design at the RCA, local residents

column2: Welcoming Workplace / Life of Work / Wellbeing & Workplace
column3: The Work & City Lab was established in HHCD in 2006 as a hub for workplace design research, bringing a novel academic perspective to understanding and supporting human interaction and experience at work. Research in the form of art and design interventions can be summarised as exploring the impact of design in four areas: influencing behaviour, enhancing experience, exploring sensation and affecting wellbeing. These human-centred perspectives present a design alternative to engineering-led efficiency in the office. The research programme has collaborated with more than 20 commercial organisations and research council funded projects, resulting in ‘3Cs’ (Concentration, Collaboration and Contemplation) office design recommendations and adoption.
column10: Helen Hamlyn Centre for Design, office workers, businesses, research associates, UKRI.

column2: Pioneering Architecture for Later Living Sector (PALLS)
column3: KTP - This project aimed to develop an inclusive, socially and economically sustainable Later Living housing model in town and city centre avoiding age segregation.
column4: Cartwright Pickard Architects. 13 selected sites were connected with/investigated in detail
column8: Cultural probes; expert interviews; shadowing; site visits; conference

column3: This was a pioneering,6-year partnership exploring the intersection of autism and design,  a field that was largely uncharted in 2010. Each year a new design brief was focussed; they ranged from workplace and garden design to the built environment and everyday activities.
column5: Six publications and a PhD dissertation. This body of research also paved the way for further projects in design and neurodivergence, in collaboration with organisations such as Paintings in Hospitals, St Andrews Healthcare, The hub, Believe in Us, Streests for Diversity ( Rees Jeffreys Road fund), Space in Mind and a scoping study for PAS 6463 ( British Standards Institution), among others.
column6: Mainly how to co-design with individuals with learning disabilties and limited verbal speech and the ethical consdierations of desiging with vulnerable indivduals
column8: This is probably the HHCD’s first project exploring co-design methods with neurodivergent people who also had additional learning disabilities and limited speech. The process of designing with people for whom language isn’t the main means of communicating was fascinating. It was also a valuable opportunity to learn how to build trust and connect empathetically with individuals who experience the world very differently from the majority.
column10:
Autism at Kingood

Ted Powers the Monument Trust and Autism at Kingwood sponsored my PhD

column3: Funded by Wellcome’s Hub Award to bring a group of very different people together to do research in new and exciting ways. Challenged the public by asking them some up close and personal questions about learning disability and human value. Imagined an alternative, more inclusive future.
column4: Very broad reaching, but focus upon researchers; performers; artists working with or having lived expereince of neurodiversity (learning disabilities; autism; brain injury etc).
column5: The 'Believe In Us' proposal was developed after this project, based on the impact of inclusive design approaches
column10: Heart n Soul; UAL Creative Computing Institute; CRAE/UCL

column2: Believe in Us - Heart & Soul and Greenwich NHS
column3: Funded by the Health Foundation. Brought together people with learning disabilties and autistic people with health and social care professionals to explore the challenges of Heathcare services and how to make them better

column2: Enhancing Future Community Connectivity for Ageing Well in Place: Co-designing Technology and Environments
column3: Co-design exploration of social housing and its relationship to community connectivity.  How can we design social housing that enables older adults to remain connected within their communities?
column4: GH residents; policy-makers (ILC); Design Futures students at the RCA
column6: Participant components of project carried out remotely
column8: cultural probes; remote co-design workshops; interviews;

column3: This study outlined a new approach to designing an inclusive London taxi for people of all ages and abilities.
column5: Information was made public, many features now exist in current Taxis. Linking back to the research may be difficult
column6: Change of CEO and CFO led to project abrupty stopping
column8: co-design workshops; vehicle design; full-scale prototyping; shadowing; interviews; audits
column10: Karsa; Hexagon; Vehicle Design Department of the RCA

column3: The Paediatric Actigraphic Clinical Evaluation (PACES) project is exploring how wearable devices could be used to evaluate interventions for children with attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD). HHCD has pioneered a child-friendly wearable device and app, jointly designed by clinicians, researchers, designers, engineers, families and children with ADHD. This device tracks activity levels, which helps understand how medication affects ADHD symptoms, and thus improving treatment for ADHD.
column4: young people with ADHD; parents; GPs; clinicians
column6: manufacture; limited budget after 18 months; RA transfered to another insitutition
